description: A plant in the family Myrtaceae, native to tropical South America’s east coast, ranging from Suriname, French Guiana to southern Brazil, as well as Uruguay and parts of Paraguay and Argentina. It is often used in gardens as a hedge or screen. The fruit is a ribbed berry, typically red to dark crimson or almost black when ripe, with a tart to sweet, resinous flavor.
seasons: Fruits multiple times a year, often spring and fall peaks
healthBenefits: Good source of Vitamin C and Vitamin A.
Contains antioxidants like lycopene and beta-cryptoxanthin.
Traditionally used for its astringent and anti-diarrheal properties.

potentialAllergies.name: Resinous Flavor
potentialAllergies.details: Some people find the resinous note in the flavor unpleasant. Darker, fully ripe fruits are usually sweeter and less resinous.

cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Climate: Tropical and subtropical. Tolerates brief, light frost once established.
2. Soil: Adaptable to a wide range of soils but prefers well-drained, slightly acidic soil.
3. Propagation: Seeds (germinate easily) or cuttings.
4. Planting: Plant in full sun to partial shade. Can be grown as a shrub or small tree, excellent for hedges.
5. Watering: Water regularly until established. Mature plants are relatively drought-tolerant.
6. Harvesting: Fruits are harvested when they are fully colored (deep red to almost black) and detach easily from the stem. They are delicate.
growthDuration: Can start fruiting in 2-3 years from seed. Fruits multiple times a year in suitable climates.
sustainabilityTips: Eat fresh when fully ripe for the best flavor (less resinous).
Excellent for making jams, jellies, and syrups due to its tartness and pectin content.
The plant is often grown ornamentally or as a hedge.
carbonFootprintInfo: Low, especially if grown locally or foraged (0.2-0.6 kg CO2e/kg).

staticRecipes.name: Fresh Surinam Cherries
staticRecipes.description: Enjoying the unique tart-sweet flavor of ripe Surinam cherries.
ingredients: A handful of ripe Surinam cherries
steps: They are best when deep red to almost black, indicating full ripeness, which reduces the resinous taste some find strong.
Eat them whole, skin and all. There is usually one or sometimes two small seeds inside, which are typically discarded.
The flavor is a unique blend of sweet, tart, and slightly resinous or spicy.

staticRecipes.name: Surinam Cherry Jam
staticRecipes.description: A flavorful jam that captures the unique taste of Surinam cherries.
ingredients: 4 cups Surinam cherries, pitted (can be tedious)
steps: Wash and pit the Surinam cherries. This may take some time as the seeds are small.
Combine pitted Surinam cherries, sugar, and lemon juice in a large, heavy-bottomed pot.
Bring the mixture to a boil over medium-high heat, stirring until sugar dissolves.
Reduce heat and simmer, stirring occasionally, for 30-45 minutes, or until the jam thickens and reaches setting point (220°F/105°C, or wrinkles on a cold plate).
Ladle hot jam into sterilized jars and seal. Process in a boiling water bath for 10 minutes if desired for longer shelf life.

staticRecipes.name: Surinam Cherry Cooler
staticRecipes.description: A refreshing drink made from Surinam cherry juice.
ingredients: 1/4 cup sugar or honey (or to taste)
steps: In a saucepan, combine Surinam cherries and 1 cup of water. Bring to a simmer and cook for 5-10 minutes, until the fruits are soft and have released their juice. Mash them gently.
Strain the mixture through a fine-mesh sieve, pressing the fruit to extract as much juice as possible. Discard solids.
Stir sugar or honey into the warm juice until dissolved. Let it cool.
To serve, fill glasses with ice. Pour about 1/4 to 1/3 cup of the Surinam cherry syrup into each glass.
Top with sparkling water or club soda. Stir gently.
